Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Academic and Cultural Identidad through Biliteracy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transforming Academic and Cultural Identidad through Biliteracy (TACIB) is a Partnership of California State University-Fullerton (CSUF), the Anaheim Union H.S. District and the Discovery Science Center as Core Partners, and Anaheim City School District and the California Association for Bilingual Education as Supporting Partners, that advances fifth to eighth grade student achievement in and attitudes toward mathematics and science through integrated dual-language/dual-immersion strategies in an urban predominantly Latino community in southern California. The TACIB prototype recognizes home linguistics and culture as assets, is integrated in multiple dimensions of the educational support system (formal, informal, pre-service, in-service, family, community, higher education), and honors and develops positive STEM identity and cultural identity among students who speak Spanish and English. TACIB further achieves its goals for middle school students and promotes sustainable outcomes by: increasing the quality and number of teachers in mathematics and science with bilingual authorization in the partner school districts; engaging parents in student science and mathematics learning; expanding the capacity of an informal science institution (Discovery Science Center) to offer programs in Spanish; developing awareness of and engagement with science and mathematics education in elementary and secondary schools among university disciplinary STEM faculty; and bolstering the capacity of CSUF to prepare bilingual teachers of science and mathematics.

Through the use of a multiple-methodology research employing qualitative and quantitative strategies, including quasi-experimental design with treatment and comparison groups, the TACIB research agenda addresses the following questions: a) What are the effects of a dual-language approach on student achievement in and attitudes toward science and mathematics?; b) What instructional activities in dual-language classrooms facilitate students' active engagement in learning science and mathematics?; and c) How does parental engagement with dual-language teachers and community partners enhance parents' knowledge of and participation in students' educational activities? Through the work of this Prototype MSP, the STEM education community will benefit from the knowledge built related to what it takes to create dynamic learning ecosystems that respect and engage the linguistic and cultural dimensions of students, families, and communities in order to promote achievement in and positive dispositions toward mathematics and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Transforming Academic and Cultural Identidad through Biliteracy (TACIB) was a Mathematics and Science Partnership project from 2013-2016 that developed and studied a mathematics and science focused, culturally and community relevant dual language academy within a high-need junior high school in southern California serving primarily Latino families. Outcomes include: a) the establishment and expansion of mathematics and science focused dual language pathways within one school district; b) the strengthening of teachers’ knowledge and skills to design and implement culturally and community relevant mathematics and science lessons in English and Spanish; and c) a positive impact on students’ interest toward STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) careers as reported on semi-annual student surveys over a two-year period.

TACIB allowed CSU Fullerton College of Education to develop a bilingual authorization program specifically for secondary teachers that supported Anaheim Union High School District (AUHSD) teachers of mathematics and science in earning bilingual authorization (authorized to teach their content area in Spanish as well as in English). As a result, AUHSD was able fully develop an academically rigorous mathematics and science focused dual language academy within one junior high school that has been replicated at a second junior high school and expanded into one high school; each of these programs features either mathematics or science coursework taught in Spanish and English by a fully credentialed bilingual authorized subject matter teacher and makes explicit efforts to connect students’ cultural and community knowledge with their academic learning. As of fall 2017 there were over 250 students enrolled in these pathways, an increase of 400% from 2013.

The TACIB project worked with twelve teachers from grades five through nine to earn bilingual authorization in Spanish and to learn about planning and enacting culturally and community relevant teaching in mathematics and science. This included making explicit connections between students’ cultural and community knowledge and content standards as well as attending to students’ participation in academic discourse and knowledge of applications of mathematics and science in different careers. Teacher self-reports showed a 46% increase in their use of these practices. Three project-based units were created, one focused on studying the ecosystem of a local river (grade seven), one examining cell phone tower placement within the local community using geometric analyses (grade eight), and the third using students’ examination of family health to learn about genetics (grade nine). In addition, AUHSD translated mathematics curriculum materials from English into Spanish for use by dual language academy students.

Based on results from a survey of students’ interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) careers given twice annually during grades seven and eight, improvement in interest toward pursuing a career in STEM was found among the dual language academy students (TACIB project participants) while peers at the same school site not enrolled in the dual language academy (control group) reported a decline in interest. Although the dual language academy students and control group students reported similar levels of interest toward STEM careers at the start of seventh grade, by the start of eighth grade (project year two) a considerably larger proportion of respondents in the dual language academy consistently selected more positive response values (for example “fascinating” or “exciting”) to describe their interest in STEM careers compared to respondents in the control group. Additionally, dual language academy students were less likely to experience a decline in interest toward STEM, something that counters the trend of declining interest in STEM found in prior research with middle grades students. Particularly noteworthy was the shift toward more positive STEM career interest among female students in TACIB, so significant there was almost no overlap when comparing their response distribution curves based on data from the surveys given at the start of year one and the surveys given at the end of year two.

Overall this project provided teachers access to collaborative professional learning about bilingual teaching and culturally responsive teaching in mathematics and science and demonstrated the impact of having teachers empowered to modify curriculum materials in mathematics and science to make them more relevant to students’ cultures and communities. Building on Latino/a middle grade students’ sense of identity, including their linguistic background, in their learning of mathematics and science led them to more positively identify with STEM careers. This work suggests a promising approach to increasing student engagement with mathematics and science education during formative middle grade years.
